column4: In Linux, filenames are case-sensitive, so yes, .iso and .ISO are different.
so what's a .ISO file then?
Both .iso and .ISO are okay (but .iso is more convienent). Actually, it may as well be .qwertyuiop, but that isn't very clear.
Maybe Daemon doesn't care about the extension either, and tries all formats known to it? foo.iso might be a NRG or whatever, and it still open.
say it is an NRG, how could I open that?
because i'm picking it's either iso or nrg
I have no idea.... hmm, what 'mount' command were you using last?
sudo mount -o loop blah.iso /mnt/xdrv
mount -t iso9660 -o loop foo.iso /mount/point
already tried that :P
This is unrelated, but why don't you simply quote the filename instead\ of\ escaping\ all\ the\ spaces?
i'll cd to the path then, but i doubt it will make much difference
It shouldn't, it's just easier to type sometimes.
Add an -t iso9660 before the -o
sudo mount -t iso9660 -o loop WarcraftIII.iso /mnt/xdrv/ ---> wrong fs type, bad option, bad superblock on /dev/loop0...
Well it is not iso9660 then? Hmmmm, head -c 1024 WarcraftIII.iso | od -h | curl -F "sprunge=<" sprunge.us
I don't know what that command does but I got this : head: cannot open `WarcraftIII.iso' for reading: No such file or directory
sorry, i was in the wrong directory. I'll try again
Eh, nevermind
that command won't actually do what I thought it does :/
any what the command you specified gave me is : curl: (26) failed creating formpost data
